content:
Je transmets l'erreur :

Le jeu a cesser de fonctionner. Veuillez contacter l'auteur(e) et transmettre l'erreur suivante :

java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index 0 out of bounds for length 0
	at java.base/jdk.internal.util.Preconditions.outOfBounds(Preconditions.java:64)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.util.Preconditions.outOfBoundsCheckIndex(Preconditions.java:70)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.util.Preconditions.checkIndex(Preconditions.java:248)
	at java.base/java.util.Objects.checkIndex(Objects.java:372)
	at java.base/java.util.ArrayList.get(ArrayList.java:458)
	at com.codingame.game.Referee.init(Referee.java:55)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.GameManager.start(GameManager.java:111)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.RefereeMain.start(RefereeMain.java:69)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.RefereeMain.main(RefereeMain.java:52)

Obtenue après le succès au test 1, et je l'ai que le test 2 soit correct ou non.
Cette erreur  a l'air aléatoire

I'm uneasy with this.

I can solve it with "a" greedy algorithm. But I can't convince myself it that alg would necessarily work on a general case. What's to say it would work on the validator cases?

As a moderator, I unfortunately don't appear to have easy access to them.

As this isn't intended for a contest, submission is “free”, so I'm theoretically fine with submit-to-check. But… I currently don't have access to that.

(if this remains a greedy puzzle, please do keep the up-to-date fire information per turn!)

Hi man, nice game. Just one quick note, total water information is not needed to solve it with a "straight forward" method. Also you should modify the inputs to read the fires only once before the loop.

I did it in python, so I don't know if it is the case for all language, but "l" is used in the pre-code for length.
Do not encourage people to use "l" or "O" as it often leads to confusion with "1" and "0".
The game is nice, maybe a test case where greedy solution is not enough would be fun. Upvoted.

Is this turn-based? Is there any relationship from one round to the next?

Why mention fire doesn't spread? (IMHO mentioning it creates more ambiguity than it solves)

The description of inputs and the template  are not coherent.

In the input descriptions it seems we have all the value once.

There is a case in which greedy would not work and it is with a 4x4 grid and 16 fires:
- Greedy: 1 canadair, 1 helicopter and 4 Jumpers = 5700
- Optimal solution: 4 helicopters = 4800

I thought to exclude this case because:
- I've yet to find a working solution (other than hardcoding it)
- It might raise the difficulty level
I thought that giving the fire coordinates on each turn would not force the player to keep track of what happens when a unit is sent

You do have access to the validators by downloading the sourcecode of the game.
My solution (which probably isn't the optimum) still has some water left.

Yes, it's a CG-rant, not an AlBlazing one.

Having to download the game is nothing; practically extracting the validation cases to assess them is a whole other can of worms.

I bit the bullet.

It was every bit as inconvenient as I expected, and then some.
Yeah you are right maybe for a second tougher version :).

Indexing should be described (0 or 1-based?)

In the constraints, I'd expect fireX and Y to be bound by L, not N
